title.p: HIV Attachment and Entry: Pursuing a Challenging Target

contrbtr_pre_content.p: WebMD Global requires each individual who is in a position to control the content of one of its educational activities to disclose any relevant financial relationships occurring within the past 12 months that could create a conflict of interest.

contrbtr_title.p: Chief, Structural Biology Section and Structural Bioinformatics Core Section, Vaccine Research Center, NIAID/NIH, Bethesda, MD, United States

contrbtr_disclsr.p: Disclosure: Peter D. Kwong, PhD, has disclosed no relevant financial relationships.
Disclosure: Marinella Calle, PhD, CMPP, has disclosed no relevant financial relationships.
Disclosure: Maria B. Uravich, BSc, has disclosed no relevant financial relationships
Disclosure: Nafeez Zawahir, MD, has disclosed no relevant financial relationships.

sec_txt.h3: Faculty
Introduction
Disclaimer
HIV-1 Entry: The First Step in the HIV-1 Life Cycle[1,2]

ul.li: The molecular machine that is at the core of HIV entry is called the HIV envelope (Env) trimer, which is placed at the surface of virus particles

sec_txt.h3: Key Viral Protein for HIV Entry[3-5]

ul.li: After the HIV virus attaches to CD4, the membrane of the virus and the host's cell surface membrane need to fuse
After the fusion process, the genetic material from the virus enters the host cell

sec_txt.h3: HIV-1 Immune Pressure and Evasion[2]

ul.li: Most viruses are not subject to huge immune pressure during the entry process
During the chronic phase of HIV infection, very high levels of antibody are present
These antibodies are trying to recognize the virus surface, where the only viral protein is the HIV Env trimer
The HIV Env trimer has evolved many ways to evade the antibody attack, differentiating itself from other viruses

sec_txt.h3: Overall Outline of Type 1 Fusion Mechanism of HIV-1 Entry Resolved 20 Years Ago[6]

ul.li: Many viruses like influenza and Ebola use the same mechanism of entry, which is called a type 1 fusion mechanism
At the very start of the HIV entry process, the glycoprotein (gp)160 protein is cleaved into the exterior gp120 protein and the transmembrane gp41 protein, which is the fusion machine

These molecules bind to CD4 and the co-receptor, and this process triggers what is called a pre-hairpin intermediate, whereby part of the fusion machinery, called the fusion peptide, is thrown into the target cell membrane
Small molecule inhibitors currently under investigation can inhibit this step and the subsequent conformational changes
If inhibition does not take place, the pre-hairpin intermediate turns into a hairpin, which then fuses membranes in a process that is not yet entirely known
Ultimately, the process ends with postfusion structures and the fusion of the viral membrane with the target cell membrane

sec_txt.h3: HIV-1 Env Entry Pathway Contains Additional Prefusion States[5]

ul.li: The Env trimer has several conformational states that it reaches in order to evade immune recognition

sec_txt.h3: Understand Entry and Immune Evasion with Atomic-Level Insights[7-9]

ul.li: The different structural states of the HIV entry process have been studied at the atomic level in an effort to design therapeutic products for HIV treatment

sec_txt.h3: Understand Entry and Immune Evasion with Atomic-Level Insights (cont) [7-9]
Outline
Link Ligand-Induced States to smFRET Measurements[10]
smFRET Tags In V1-V4 Sample Conformational Flexibility of HIV-1 Env Trimer on Infectious Virus[10]
Functional Env Trimer Transitions Between 3 Prefusion Conformation States[10]

ul.li: Viruses such as influenza or Ebola have a single prefusion conformation state
With HIV, the Env trimer transitions between different states

sec_txt.h3: State 1 Was Preferentially Recognized by Most Broadly Neutralizing Antibodies[10]

ul.li: Adding certain antibodies will force the Env molecule into a particular state
This effect occurs with many antibodies, and also with small molecules such as temsavir (formerly BMS-626529)
Both laboratory-adapted virus and primary isolate show similar responses, meaning that this process is a "general" way that the HIV Env trimer uses to enter cells

sec_txt.h3: Determination of Env Trimer Structure Used 2 Antibodies For Crystallization[11]
Initial Interaction of CD4 With the HIV-1 Env Trimer[12]
Measurement of smFRET Directly on Soluble Env Trimers[12-14]

ul.li:
The initial single-molecule fluorescence resonance energy transfer (smFRET) measurements were performed on the surface of the infectious virus
The crystal structures are actually solubilized protein
An alternative way to study these structures is to take the solubilized protein, the trimer, place the smFRET tags, attach these to a glass slide, and look at the smFRET measurements

sec_txt.h3: Insights on Structure of Env Trimers[13,15,16]
Structural Transformation: State 2 to State 3[7,16]
Summary: HIV-1 Env Structure
Outline
Inhibitors That Bind to States 1 and 2 Neutralize Primary Isolates; Those That Only Bind State 3 Often Do Not[5,17]

ul.li: The way HIV evades the immune system is by staying in state 1 and state 2, and only roughly transitioning to state 3 when it needs to enter the host cell
Therefore, the best entry inhibitors are those that can bind to state 1 and state 2

sec_txt.h3: Entry Inhibitors and Targets[18-24]
Fostemsavir (BMS-663068)[25,26]

ul.li: The small molecule temsavir is a very potent attachment inhibitor; however, it has poor biological activity due to its hydrophobic nature
Addition of a methyl phosphate to the structure results in the small molecule called fostemsavir (BMS-663068), which has very good bioavailability

sec_txt.h3: Fostemsavir: BRIGHTE Phase 3 Study[24,27]
Crystal Structures of HIV-1-Env Trimer With BMS-378806 and Its Derivative, Temsavir[11,28]
Lattice-Chaperone Strategy: Mutations for Improvement[29]
Summary: Chaperone Mutations for Improvement[29]

ul.li: Approximately twice as much information (vs what was previously available) is obtained by using the lattice-chaperone strategy
Structures can now be read at about 3 Å

sec_txt.h3: New Lattice Appears to Be Improved[7,11,29,30]
New Crystal Allows for the Determination of Structures With Trimers From Diverse HIV-1 Strains[29]

ul.li: New lattice also allows researchers to look for HIV-1 variability

The crystal lattice currently available is composed purely of antibodies binding to the Env trimer; with these in place, crystals can be formed using all sorts of different trimers captured within the crystal lattice
This technique has allowed the observation of the small molecule BMS-386150 bound to different HIV strains

sec_txt.h3: Co-Crystal Structures Show Potential Additional Functional Group
Structural "Freezing" by Temsavir binding[16,28]
Summary: Small Molecule Entry Inhibitors
Concluding Remarks
Thank You

p.em: This content has been condensed for improved clarity.

slide_intro.p:
3D = three-dimensional
AE = adverse event
ART = antiretroviral therapy
BID = twice daily
CCR5 = C-C chemokine receptor type 5
CXCR = CXC chemokine receptor
CXCR4 = CXC chemokine receptor type 4
Env = envelope
Fab = antigen-binding fragment
gp = glycoprotein
GPCR = G-protein-coupled receptor
HTE = heavily treatment-experienced
Ig = immunoglobulin
rxn = resolution
smFRET = single-molecule fluorescence resonance energy transfer

bkmtr_front.p: The educational activity presented above may involve simulated case-based scenarios. The patients depicted in these scenarios are fictitious and no association with any actual patient is intended or should be inferred.

The material presented here does not necessarily reflect the views of WebMD Global, LLC or companies that support educational programming on medscape.org. These materials may discuss therapeutic products that have not been approved by the European Medicines Agency for use in Europe and off-label uses of approved products. A qualified healthcare professional should be consulted before using any therapeutic product discussed. Readers should verify all information and data before treating patients or employing any therapies described in this educational activity.
